replies.msg:
History of the American Motion Picture

Right after World War II, Eric Johnston, former President of the United States Chamber of Commerce, became president of what would become the MPAA. Johnston saw in Hollywood the opportunity to shape the perceptions of America domestically and internationally, seeing that “the motion picture industry is the most powerful medium for the influencing of people that man has ever built” and that Hollywood could, in effect, help to reinvent America by helping to shape a new popular consensus of American life. This new “consensus” was rooted not in regionalism or the differences in Americans that were celebrated in the 1920s—when jazz was the hot trend—and 1930s—when ethnic actors such as Will Rogers and James Cagney dominated Hollywood—but, rather, in uniformity. Johnston, knowing that films were now being shipped to post-war Europe, believed films should show a united country rooted in consumerism, not films such as The Grapes of Wrath, which showed what he called “the seamy side of American life.” To that end, he encouraged movies that celebrated American myth and, especially, American opportunity. And while Hollywood did produce some exceptions by and large, films produced between 1946 and 1967 (the beginning of the so-called “New Hollywood” with the release of Bonnie and Clyde and The Graduate) suggest an idealized America rooted in traditional values, standard gender roles, and a belief in capitalism and the family.

Take 1946’s It’s a Wonderful Life, for instance. Even though there is a corrupt banker in the film, the good deeds of the main character save the day and rid the bank of its past corruption, allowing for a glorious American future. Or, for another example, try 1948’s Fort Apache, a Western that both proves the myth of Custer’s Last Stand to be, well, a myth, while also celebrating that myth. The film ends with the hero figure describing the greatness of the Custer-esque colonel that is the film’s central bad guy. Why? Because the myth of America is ultimately more important than the truth. This is exactly the sort of message Johnston endorsed, for, ultimately, Johnston was far more concerned with showing an idealized country than a realized one.

replies.msg: This is very impressive and well done. Your complex grammar and vocabulary surpass even many native English speakers. Your grammar is impeccable, and I have nothing to carp about. Admittedly, your essay is very well written even compared to native writers!

你呢篇應該係學術文章黎？我見你一開頭啲sentence structure係好長好formal，但係碌一碌落下面，哇，the film's central bad guy係咩料？齣戲嘅主要反角？你唔好再chinglish啲？同埋acedemic writing好少會用 rhetorical question，你仲要係Why?完直接Because開頭，你唔係寫緊演講稿啊清

其他grammar野、結構同內容都未詳細睇，陣間再講
